concept.title: Example: Using chunk to combine all documents into one
concept.shortdesc: When a processor would typically render each topic document as an independent result document, the chunk attribute can be used to render all content as a single document.

fig.title: Root map and the topics that it references
fig.codeblock: <map> <title>Lesson plan</title> <topicref href="background.dita"> <!-- More topic references to background topics --> </topicref> <topicref href="goals.dita"> <!-- More topic references to goal topics --> </topicref> <!-- More topic references --> </map>
fig.p: The following code samples show the content of background.dita and goals.dita:
fig.codeblock: <!-- Content of background.dita --> <topic id="background"> <title>Prerequisite concepts</title> <shortdesc>This information is necessary before starting ...</shortdesc> <body> <!-- ... --> </body> </topic>
<!-- Content of goals.dita --> <topic id="goals"> <title>Lesson goals</title> <shortdesc>After you complete the lesson ...</shortdesc> <body> <!-- ... --> </body> </topic>

conbody.p: For many systems or output formats, each document in the map is typically rendered as an independent document. For example, rendering this map as HTML5 might result in background.html and goals.html, in addition to other HTML5 files.

fig.title: Root map with chunking specified
fig.p: If the output requirements demand only a single result document, specifying chunk="combine" on the root map element instructs a processor to render a single document that combines all topics:
fig.codeblock: <map chunk="combine"> <title>Lesson plan</title> <topicref href="background.dita"> <!-- More topic references to background topics --> </topicref> <topicref href="goals.dita"> <!-- More topic references to goal topics --> </topicref> <!-- More topic references --> </map>

fig.title: Equivalent content of source documents after evaluation
fig.p: The result of evaluating the chunk attribute is equivalent to the following map and topic documents:
fig.codeblock: <dita> <!-- original content of background.dita --> <topic id="background"> <title>Prerequisite concepts</title> <shortdesc>This information is necessary before starting</shortdesc> <body> <!-- ... --> </body> <!-- More background topics --> </topic> <!-- original content of goals.dita --> <topic id="goals"> <title>Lesson goals</title> <shortdesc>After you complete the lesson ...</shortdesc> <body> <!-- ... --> </body> <!-- More goal topics --> </topic> <!-- More topics --> </dita>
fig.p: The content from all topics within the map is combined into a single result document, with a topic order and topic nesting structure that matches the original map hierarchy:
